 And here's the answer, it was the Apple Laserwriter. I should apologize right at the outset.

fuse the toner ink,

RS-232, a serial line,
RS-422. Now that's an adaptation of the ISO standard that, in the Apple domain, was called "Appletalk".
It's a medium speed network. It's better than serial line.
Appletalk could do 230 kilobits.
230 kilobits is okay, but it's not Ethernet.
Early Ethernet is 10 megabits, way faster again.
So you've got a network of sorts, but not a very high-speed one. It's telling you how many fonts there are inside it.

that was a lot in those days. And it wasn't
there to support a multitasking game-playing machine,
it was there simply and solely to support font rendering to the laser printer drum.

clock speed. By the time it got to this laser printer
 over here,

is that if you've got your page all bitmapped and rendered and ready to go and,
you know, an A4 or US letter size page, you're talking about a megabyte, you're talking 8 megabits' worth of
black and white dots.
But once inside here, you tell the drum to start imaging stuff on the paper,
and you start rolling the paper out. You are committed. You can't say "Stop, I want to do the bottom half a bit later,
I'm running out of out of compute power". You can't do that. When you got to go,
you got to go. Some of you have seen the previous videos on the
202 Typesetter, can sort of draw the contrast here. The 202 had the great advantage that it was all done in
letterbox strips, the imaging onto a reel of paper.
And if you, after you turn one letterbox full, you wanted to go away
and have a cup of tea before you did the rest, well then, you could. There's no problem. But not with this.
It's utterly page-based. When you roll, you've got to roll,
you can't stop. And it was a huge demand to be able to keep up with the roll-out speed of this.
And believe me, it was only just doable,
particularly with Laserwriter I technology.
There were 13 fonts inside the earlier one. When I say fonts, you know, what would the 13 have been? Four flavours of Times Roman,
regular, bold, bold italic, and italic, four flavours of Helvetica,
ordinary, oblique, so on... four flavours of Courier, a fixed-pitch font,

heard of." So he won the day, and I think he was right.

 all sharing the Appletalk.

John Warnock and Steve Jobs rehearsing and discussing how they were going to present this

 John realized that what he had to do,

So is this the birth of PDF? Yes.
having to do this gave John the idea

that this was the way to unroll Postscript 
to make it longer,
but faster and more predictable as to how many pages it will produce. Because the problem with Postscript in its pure form is,
